results.title: Fighting Warrior  for Spectrum 48K
results.creator_credit: Stephen Cargill, Melbourne House and Studio B
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette and cover in a plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description: Fighting Warrior [computer game]. Fighting Warrior is a single player side scrolling fighting game. Players have a high, mid and low attack, jump, duck and step back and must fight oncoming enemies in one on one combat.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stephen Cargill, Melbourne House and Studio B

results.title: Fist II - The Legend Continues for ZX Spectrum 48/128
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and paper insert in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description: Fist II - The Legend Continues [computer game]. Fist II is a single player side scrolling beat ‘em up with adventure elements. Players travel through different environments, fighting various enemies, collecting items and visiting temples to power up the character to be strong enough to defeat the warlord and free the land.
results.title_for_label: Fist II - The Legend Continues for ZX Spectrum 48/128
results.description: Fist II - The Legend Continues [computer game]. Fist II is a single player side scrolling beat ‘em up with adventure elements. Players travel through different environments, fighting various enemies, collecting items and visiting temples to power up the character to be strong enough to defeat the warlord and free the land.
description_for_label: Fist II - The Legend Continues [computer game]. Fist II is a single player side scrolling beat ‘em up with adventure elements. Players travel through different environments, fighting various enemies, collecting items and visiting temples to power up the character to be strong enough to defeat the warlord and free the land.

results.title: Doc the Destroyer for Commodore 64/128
results.creator_credit: Geoff Evans, Paul Kidd, Melbourne House and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and manual booklet in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description: Doc the Destroyer [computer game]. Doc the Destroyer is a side view, strategy arcade adventure in a post apocalyptic setting for one player. At the start of the game, players are given 60 points which they can distribute between five statistics Strength, Endurance, Intelligence, Luck and Charisma. As Doc, players are presented with various choices that determine your next action and some will throw the player into arcade styled combat.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Geoff Evans, Paul Kidd, Melbourne House and Beam Software
results.description: Doc the Destroyer [computer game]. Doc the Destroyer is a side view, strategy arcade adventure in a post apocalyptic setting for one player. At the start of the game, players are given 60 points which they can distribute between five statistics Strength, Endurance, Intelligence, Luck and Charisma. As Doc, players are presented with various choices that determine your next action and some will throw the player into arcade styled combat.
description_for_label: Doc the Destroyer [computer game]. Doc the Destroyer is a side view, strategy arcade adventure in a post apocalyptic setting for one player. At the start of the game, players are given 60 points which they can distribute between five statistics Strength, Endurance, Intelligence, Luck and Charisma. As Doc, players are presented with various choices that determine your next action and some will throw the player into arcade styled combat.

results.title: The Tolkien Trilogy  for Commodore 64
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Two cassettes, paper manual, plastic cassette tray in a cardboard case
results.brief_description: Contains three games: ‘The Hobbit’, ‘Lord of the Rings’ and ‘Shadows of Mordor’. The games are loosely based on “The Hobbit” and “The Lord of the Rings” novels by J.R.R Tolkien

results.title: Bedlam for ZX Spectrum 128/+2
results.creator_credit: GO! Media Holdings Ltd and Beam Software
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description: Bedlam [computer game]. Bedlam is a top down vertical shooting scroller in a futuristic sci fi setting for one or two players simultaneously. Players pilot a vehicle shooting and dodging aliens and fighting boss ships.

results.title: Demon Stalkers for Commodore 64/128
results.creator_credit: Electronic Arts and Micro Forte Studios
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, code wheel, warranty card & manual (paper booklet) in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
Demon Stalkers is an action RPG and editor/construction set game. It is similar to Atari’s Gauntlet. The player can choose either the hero, armed with throwing knives, or the heroine, armed with a crossbow who must travel through ninety-nine mazes before meeting the final demon. The game features different enemies as you progress through the mazes, with clues to progression built in. There is also a two-player co-operative mode. The in-built level editor uses pull-down menus and offers a high level of flexibility. As well as creating actual levels, the player can create an integrated storyline and game world, since the in-game text can also be edited.
The game shipped with a Magic Cipher consisting of three cardboard wheels that, when moved to the correct positions, revealed the passwords were needed to access some of the lower levels of the dungeon. Some of the vital text in the cipher is in a tone of blue that could not be photocopied at that point, making the cipher a basic anti-piracy measure.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/demon-stalkers/

Last accessed: 14/04/2021

Original game developed by Micro Forte Studios for Commodore 64 and 128, published in 1987 by Electronic Arts.
results.description:
Demon Stalkers is an action RPG and editor/construction set game. It is similar to Atari’s Gauntlet. The player can choose either the hero, armed with throwing knives, or the heroine, armed with a crossbow who must travel through ninety-nine mazes before meeting the final demon. The game features different enemies as you progress through the mazes, with clues to progression built in. There is also a two-player co-operative mode. The in-built level editor uses pull-down menus and offers a high level of flexibility. As well as creating actual levels, the player can create an integrated storyline and game world, since the in-game text can also be edited.
The game shipped with a Magic Cipher consisting of three cardboard wheels that, when moved to the correct positions, revealed the passwords were needed to access some of the lower levels of the dungeon. Some of the vital text in the cipher is in a tone of blue that could not be photocopied at that point, making the cipher a basic anti-piracy measure.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/demon-stalkers/

Last accessed: 14/04/2021

The player can choose either the hero, armed with throwing knives, or the heroine, armed with a crossbow who must travel through ninety-nine mazes before meeting the final demon. results.title: The Woods
results.material_description: Multi-channel installation, video, colour and audio
results.brief_description: The Woods is a video installation comprised of three documentaries on child film stars from the United States of America, Nigeria and India. ‘The Audition’ features Hollywood stars, ‘The Interview’ features Nollywood stars, and ‘The Rehearsal’ features Bollywood stars. The Woods was exhibited at ACMI as part of The Character exhibition in 2015.
results.description: The Woods is a video installation comprised of three documentaries on child film stars from the United States of America, Nigeria and India. ‘The Audition’ features Hollywood stars, ‘The Interview’ features Nollywood stars, and ‘The Rehearsal’ features Bollywood stars. results.title: The Hobbit
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette & paper booklet in black box
results.brief_description:
“The Hobbit” computer game for BBC Model B.
“The Hobbit” is a single-player text adventure game, originally released for the games platform ZX Spectrum 48K. It was subsequently released for other platforms including BBC. (See Documentation window for full list of game releases).
The adventure is based on J.R.R. Tolkien’s famous book of the same name.
The game cassette is accompanied by a manual with information about the game. Game cassette and manual are contained in a black cardboard box.

constellations_other.name: A world of firsts
constellations_other.description: There’s a first time for everything. In their own way, these films, television and videogames each broke ground.

results.description:
The Hobbit was one of the first major games produced in Australia, and is considered a classic text adventure. In 1985, it was voted number 1 in Sinclair User’s ‘Top 50 Spectrum Software Classics’.

To create the game Beam’s director Alfred Milgrom advertised on the bulletin board at Melbourne University hiring students Veronika Megler and Philip Mitchell. Originally tasked with making the “best adventure game ever’. Milgrom secured a licence to use J.R.R Tolkien’s popular book the The Hobbit by using Melbourne House’s book publishing relationships, and promising that a copy of the book was to be included with the game. The inclusion of the book with the game was also valuable to the player, as knowledge of the story was needed to solve the challenges that Megler had designed.

The Hobbit was remarkable for both its sophisticated parser and creation of a world that appeared open – were time passed, objects had physics and characters autonomy.

The games interface, Philip Mitchell’s parser Inglish allowed for full sentences with adjectives, where previously most adventure games only allowed for simpler verb-noun combinations. The program was complex enough to intuitively understand pronouns, adverbs, punctuation and prepositions. This allowed players to interact with the games in a way never before possible. Commands could be strung together not just to control the actions of the player character but with the inclusion of “SAY” directive could be issued to non player characters .

In designing the game world Megler wanted to create a place that felt more alive. Objects in the game are given a size and weight ratio which affects your ability to interact with them. You could place one object inside or on top of another. If your character was sitting on an object and that object was thrown, then your character would go with it. Another point of difference with this game and any previous text-based adventure game was that events happened in real time. If you walked away from the computer things would happen with out you. As you played each non-player character and monster had a turn when you did, meaning that many unforeseen events could occur, Elrond might kill the Warg making your journey less troublesome. Gandalf might get himself killed making that game more challenging. The set of characters actions were in part randomised but also affected by the actions of the player so attacking them was not a good idea. As was learnt by many players who became impatient with Thorin and his constant singing. At this time the expression “Thorin sits down and starts singing about gold.” entered the popular culture of gamers.

Players found The Hobbit constantly appealing because non-player characters existed independently. They were able to roam freely through the game-world and would not necessarily do the same thing twice. This and the games text driven physics enabled the game to be repeated and played in different ways. Due to the openness of its world, “The Hobbit” was an early game to support ‘emergent gameplay’.

The Hobbit was a challenging game to play requiring trail and error to progress and solve puzzles. Letters requesting assistance were sent to popular magazines who devoted columns to advising players. One player David Elkan wrote an entire guide to playing the game which he sent to Melbourne House who published it as book ” A guide to playing The Hobbit (1984).

References: ACMI Alfred Milgrom interview, 28 April 2006: Interview text provided by Alfred Milgrom 1st March 2013. , Maher, J, “The Hobbit”, The Digital Antiquarian, http://www.filfre.net/2012/11/the-hobbit/; Newman J, Simons, I (2007) 100 Videogames, BFI Screen Guides, BFI Publishing, London

This version of The Hobbit is for the BBC Model B. The game cassette is accompanied by a manual with information about the game. Game cassette and manual are contained in a black cardboard box.

results.title: You and I, Horizontal II
results.material_description: computer, computer script, projector and  haze machine
results.brief_description:
Step into a dark haze-filled room to interact with the power of projected light. Transforming a beam of light into a three-dimensional sculpture, Anthony McCall’s ‘You and I, Horizontal II’ (2006) is an Australian premiere.

The pioneering work of British-born artist Anthony McCall occupies a space between sculpture, cinema, performance and drawing. McCall was one of the first visual artists to experiment with spatial film and temporal sculpture, emerging in the mid 1970s with the ‘Solid Light’ film series - works that used a 16mm projector to project cones of light through smoke or haze filled rooms. His work attracted renewed attention in the 1990s, when spatial installations once again became a popular and critical tendency in contemporary art. He now uses digital projection and complex graphic software systems to capture the most basic sensory element of the moving image: the projection of light.
